q: What is the main role of an operating system?
choices: Manage hardware and provide services for applications
explain: The OS manages hardware resources and provides an interface for applications.

q: Which component of an OS interacts directly with hardware?
explain: The kernel controls hardware resources and core functions.

q: Which OS component provides a user interface for typing commands?
explain: The shell provides the interface for user commands (CLI or GUI).

q: A graphical interface with windows, icons, and menus is called:
explain: GUI = Graphical User Interface.

q: Multitasking means:
choices: OS can handle multiple processes seemingly at the same time
Only one user can log in
explain: Multitasking allows concurrent execution of multiple processes.

q: A thread is:
choices: A lightweight unit of a process
explain: Threads are subdivisions of a process that share resources.

q: Difference between 32-bit and 64-bit OS:
explain: 64-bit OS can address much larger amounts of RAM.

q: Which OS type controls hardware in a printer or router?
explain: Embedded OS is built into devices like printers and routers.

q: Which OS is UNIX-based and widely used on Apple computers?
explain: macOS is derived from UNIX.

q: Which OS kernel is open-source and used in many distributions?
explain: Linux is an open-source kernel with many distros.

q: Which Microsoft OS introduced the GUI widely to PCs?
explain: Windows 3.x brought GUI to a wide PC audience.

q: Which OS is cloud-centric and lightweight, used on Chromebooks?
explain: ChromeOS is designed for cloud and web apps.

q: iOS and Android are examples of:
explain: They are mobile operating systems.

q: Which file system is common in Windows?
explain: NTFS is the standard Windows file system.

q: Which file system is default in many Linux distributions?
explain: EXT4 is widely used in Linux.

q: Which file system is default in macOS?
explain: Apple File System (APFS) is used in macOS.

q: Which Windows utility lists running processes?
explain: Task Manager shows processes and system resource usage.

q: Which command-line tool shows files and directories in Linux/macOS?
explain: `ls` lists directory contents in Linux/macOS.

q: Which Linux command is used to change file permissions?
explain: `chmod` changes file permissions.

q: Metadata in a file system refers to:
explain: Metadata describes properties of the file.

q: Which OS feature restricts user access to resources?
explain: Access control defines user rights and permissions.

q: Device drivers are needed because:
choices: They allow the OS to communicate with hardware
explain: Drivers are software that let the OS control hardware.

q: Which Linux distribution is often used for servers?
explain: Ubuntu Server and similar Linux distros power many servers.

q: What does UAC (User Account Control) do in Windows?
choices: Prevents unauthorized changes by prompting for permission
explain: UAC protects against unauthorized system changes.

q: Which OS lab in your Notion is used to practice Debian commands?
explain: Debian is used in VMware Player lab for practice.

q: Which term describes OS code that anyone can inspect and modify?
explain: Open source code is publicly available for viewing and modification.

q: What is the primary responsibility of the kernel?
choices: Managing CPU, memory, and I/O scheduling
explain: The kernel manages core resources and I/O scheduling.

q: What is a shell?
choices: A user interface over the kernel (CLI or GUI)
explain: The shell accepts user commands and talks to the kernel.

q: Cooperative multitasking risk:
choices: One frozen app can hang the system
explain: Apps must yield CPU; a hung app can stall the system.

q: Preemptive multitasking benefit:
choices: OS time-slices apps to protect system stability
explain: The scheduler enforces time slices to keep system responsive.

q: Multithreading in one process enables:
choices: Parallel or concurrent tasks inside a single app
explain: Threads allow concurrent tasks within a process.

q: Which statement about 64-bit OS is true?
choices: Addresses far more than 4 GB RAM
explain: 64-bit architectures expand the address space dramatically.

q: UNIX became widely used partly because:
choices: Source was distributed broadly from Bell Labs
explain: Bell Labs shared UNIX widely; it was portable and fast.

q: Which system pioneered the desktop GUI concepts later used by many OSs?
explain: Xerox Star introduced the windowed desktop paradigm.

q: Windows XP unified which lines?
choices: Consumer and business on the NT kernel
explain: XP unified consumer and business on NT.

q: What major UI change did Windows 8 introduce?
explain: Windows 8 replaced Start menu with a tile-based Start screen.

q: macOS is certified as:
explain: Modern macOS releases are UNIX-certified.

q: ChromeOS primary design goal:
explain: ChromeOS centers on web apps and cloud storage.

q: ChromeOS Flex is used to:
choices: Install ChromeOS-like system on old PCs/Macs
explain: ChromeOS Flex refreshes older hardware with a ChromeOS-style OS.

q: Which best describes a Linux distribution?
choices: Linux kernel plus userland, desktop, and tools
explain: A distro includes the kernel and supporting components.

q: Which desktop environment item is typical of macOS?
explain: macOS uses the Dock for launching and switching.

q: Which utility on macOS monitors CPU and memory in real time?
explain: Activity Monitor shows processes and resource use.

q: How do you quickly open System Information on macOS?
choices:  menu while holding Option > System Information…
explain: Hold Option and open System Information from the Apple menu.

q: Disk Utility is used to:
choices: Partition and format disks and manage volumes
explain: Disk Utility manages partitions, file systems, and volumes.

q: Formatting a partition creates:
choices: A file system structure on the partition
explain: Formatting lays down the file system structures.

q: Reformatting a volume will:
explain: Reformatting erases existing data.

q: Which file system feature improves crash recovery?
explain: Journaling logs intended changes for safer recovery.

q: Which is most cross-compatible for USB sticks?
explain: FAT32 has wide OS compatibility despite limitations.

q: UDF is mainly used for:
explain: UDF is common on DVDs and Blu‑ray discs.

q: APFS advantages include:
explain: APFS supports snapshots, encryption, and SSD-friendly design.

q: NTFS supports which features?
explain: NTFS includes modern FS features like ACLs and EFS.

q: Where do you manage user accounts in macOS?
explain: Users & Groups manages accounts and roles.

q: Which macOS account type has full control?
explain: Admins can change system-wide settings and manage users.

q: Access control on macOS commonly appears as:
choices: Admin authentication prompts for sensitive actions
explain: macOS prompts for admin credentials to protect system changes.

q: Typical steps to install apps outside the App Store on macOS:
choices: Open .dmg and drag app to Applications
explain: Most Mac apps install by dragging from a mounted DMG.

q: How to uninstall most macOS apps:
choices: Drag app from Applications to Trash
explain: Many apps can be removed by dragging to Trash.

q: Which describes a background service on UNIX-like systems?
explain: Background services are often called daemons on UNIX-like OSs.

q: Which tool lists and can kill processes on macOS?
explain: Activity Monitor can force-quit misbehaving processes.

q: What is launchd on macOS?
choices: A service and job manager for starting daemons
explain: launchd loads and manages system/user services and jobs.

q: Which utility shows complete hardware inventories on macOS?
explain: System Information enumerates hardware and kext details.

q: Which statement about servers is accurate?
choices: They provide resources to clients over a network
explain: Servers expose services like auth, files, and printing to clients.

q: Windows Server naming convention uses:
explain: Modern Windows Server versions use year-based names.

q: Status of macOS Server:
explain: Apple discontinued macOS Server in 2022.

q: FreeBSD differs from Linux primarily because:
choices: It is a complete OS with a more permissive license
explain: FreeBSD is a full OS with a permissive BSD license.

q: Android is based on:
explain: Android uses a Linux-based kernel.

q: Since Android 10, versioning emphasizes:
explain: Google shifted emphasis to numeric versions starting with 10.

q: iOS and iPadOS share a foundation with:
explain: Apple’s desktop and mobile OSs share UNIX roots.

q: Where is the macOS Activity Monitor located?
explain: Activity Monitor resides in /Applications/Utilities.

q: Which Terminal command shows a manual page?
explain: Use `man <command>` to read the manual page.

q: Finder’s Get Info window can show:
choices: File size, type, location, and permissions
explain: Get Info displays key metadata and permissions.

q: Locking a file in Finder sets which flag on macOS?
explain: Locked files show the uchg flag in `ls -lo`.

q: Which command removes the locked state in the exercise?
explain: Adding write permission clears the user immutable flag in the exercise flow.

q: The root of the UNIX-like directory tree is:
explain: Root is represented by `/`.

q: Your home folder path template is:
explain: User homes are under /Users on macOS.

q: Which view helps find hardware model numbers and driver versions?
explain: System Information lists model and kext details.

q: When is it safest to kill a process?
explain: Prefer killing only stuck user apps; avoid critical system processes.

q: Primary difference between desktop and server OS in this course:
choices: Servers add services and scaling features
explain: Server editions emphasize services, concurrency, and management.

q: Which statement about file permissions is correct?
choices: They are unrelated to access control
They define read/write/execute rights for users and groups
explain: Permissions enforce access control at the file system level.
